<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 670, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 122]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1700\mathrm{kg}\) moves in a straight line along a slope that is at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 816, 407]]<|/det|>
The car moves at constant velocity for a distance of \(25\mathrm{m}\) from point A to point B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 403, 920, 438]]<|/det|>
Air resistance and friction provide a total resistive force of \(440\mathrm{N}\) that opposes the motion of the car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 494, 470]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 181, 501]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A child sits on the ground next to a remote-controlled toy car. At time \(t = 0\), the car begins to move in a straight line directly away from the child. The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity of the car along this line is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 134, 722, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 299, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
The car's horn continually emits sound of frequency \(925\mathrm{Hz}\) between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = 6.0\mathrm{s}\). The speed of the sound in the air is \(338\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 376, 146, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
Describe qualitatively the variation, if any, in the frequency of the sound heard, by the child, that was emitted from the car horn:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 422, 180, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 422, 448, 441]]<|/det|>
from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 2.0 \text{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 546, 920, 580]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A tube is initially fully submerged in water. The axis of the tube is kept vertical as the tube is slowly raised out of the water, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 114, 752, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 367, 500, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
A loudspeaker producing sound of frequency \(530\mathrm{Hz}\) is positioned at the open top end of the tube as it is raised. The water surface inside the tube is always level with the water surface outside the tube. The speed of the sound in the air column in the tube is \(340\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
Describe a simple way that a student, without requiring any additional equipment, can detect when a stationary wave is formed in the air column as the tube is being raised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 146, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
Determine the height of the top end of the tube above the surface of the water when a stationary wave is first produced in the tube. Assume that an antinode is formed level with the top of the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 816, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>height = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance moved by the tube between the positions at which the first and second stationary waves are formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 210, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = .................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 900, 91]]<|/det|>
A cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(0.48 \text{V}\) is connected to a metal wire X, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 100, 687, 257]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 278, 554, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 645, 329]]<|/det|>
The cell has internal resistance. The current in the cell is \(0.80 \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 341, 794, 359]]<|/det|>
Wire X has length \(3.0 \text{m}\), cross-sectional area \(1.3 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}^2\) and resistance \(0.40 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 144, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 732, 390]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = .................................................... C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 146, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 556, 813, 576]]<|/det|>
Calculate the percentage efficiency with which the cell supplies power to wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>efficiency = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 834, 89]]<|/det|>
There are \(3.2 \times 10^{22}\) free (conduction) electrons contained in the volume of wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 332, 120]]<|/det|>
For wire X, calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 134, 541, 152]]<|/det|>
the number density \(n\) of the free electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 225, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
<form>n = .................................................... m⁻³ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 256, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 256, 561, 275]]<|/det|>
the average drift speed of the free electrons.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 425, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
\[\text{average drift speed} = \text{...............................................} \text{ms}^{-1} \text{[2]}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 146, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
A wire Y has the same cross-sectional area as wire X and is made of the same metal. Wire Y is longer than wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
Wire X in the circuit is now replaced by wire Y. Assume that wire Y has the same temperature as wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 920, 585]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the average drift speed of the free electrons in wire Y is greater than, the same as, or less than that in wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[856, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 784, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>

BEFORE DECAY

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[534, 217, 667, 235]]<|/det|>
AFTER DECAY

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 541, 304]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 643, 676]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 873, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = ................................................. MeV

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 874, 920, 892]]<|/det|>

A graph of number of neutrons \(N\) against proton number \(Z\) is shown in Fig. 7.2.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 333, 500, 352]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 584, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 747, 445]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 521, 473, 540]]<|/det|>
